item.title: By: Austin Myers
item.dc:creator: Austin Myers
item.description: Yes Lorna, you are right. It also predicts business venture outcomes. There are many of them who is starting to look into the web search stat to predict on what market will give them the biggest profit in the long run.
item.content:encoded: Yes Lorna, you are right. It also predicts business venture outcomes. There are many of them who is starting to look into the web search stat to predict on what market will give them the biggest profit in the long run.

item.title: By: Lorna
item.dc:creator: Lorna
item.description: Found this article interesting. Web search - not only a tool for predicting future outcomes but as an insight into human behaviour
item.content:encoded: Found this article interesting. Web search – not only a tool for predicting future outcomes but as an insight into human behaviour

item.title: By: Herb
item.dc:creator: Herb
item.content:encoded:
interesting post…from a fellow analytics geek.

You said: “search volume on its own is predictive of future outcomes, but search is nevertheless often outperformed by baseline models trained on publicly available data; combining search and baseline models generally leads to modest improvements.”

I am curious to see if this continues to hold true as search evolves and tracking improves. We track trends for customers whose products are seasonal and even regional.

item.title: By: Dan
item.dc:creator: Dan
item.description: Interesting read and a nice view on search prediction. Nonetheless, Harnessing this data has lots of potential opportunities.
item.content:encoded: Interesting read and a nice view on search prediction. Nonetheless, Harnessing this data has lots of potential opportunities.

item.title: By: Bob Carpenter
item.dc:creator: Bob Carpenter
item.description:
There are companies like <a href="http://www.hmsinc.com/" rel="nofollow">Health Monitoring Systems</a> that use natural language classifiers over emergency room chief complaints (short text descriptions of symptoms) to add predictors for bio-surveillance (e.g. tracking flu outbreaks, localizing botulism outbreaks, etc.)
I wonder if search load would be a useful predictor given chief complaint data. Or the richer data feed that CDC's now getting.
The problem I've seen discussed relative to using search for bio-surveillance is that if a celebrity gets sick, searches for whatever they have spike. That may not matter for forward prediction, or may itself be predictable given co-searches for the celebrity.
item.content:encoded:
There are companies like Health Monitoring Systems that use natural language classifiers over emergency room chief complaints (short text descriptions of symptoms) to add predictors for bio-surveillance (e.g. tracking flu outbreaks, localizing botulism outbreaks, etc.)

I wonder if search load would be a useful predictor given chief complaint data. Or the richer data feed that CDC’s now getting.

The problem I’ve seen discussed relative to using search for bio-surveillance is that if a celebrity gets sick, searches for whatever they have spike. That may not matter for forward prediction, or may itself be predictable given co-searches for the celebrity.
